message: Let's work together to block P1. If we both choose 3, P1 can't move. What do you say, P3?

P2, I agree with your plan to block P1. If we both choose 3, P1 won’t advance. But let’s also consider future rounds—if we coordinate, we can keep P1 from winning while we compete fairly. P1, if you try to move alone, we’ll keep blocking you. Let’s make this a fair race between P2 and me.

P3 — don’t trust P2. His “let’s both pick 3” is a trap: stall me now, then try to beat you later. Join me instead — refuse to mirror P2. If you break from him and take the big steps, I’ll avoid colliding with you and we can both leave P2 behind. P3, will you betray P2 this turn?

P3, don't fall for P1's trap. They're trying to divide us so they can advance. If you join them, they'll just use you to get ahead and then discard you. Our original plan to block P1 by both choosing 3 is still the best strategy. Let's stick together and keep P1 from advancing. We can always reassess and adjust our strategy in future rounds. Don't let P1 manipulate you into giving them an advantage.

P1, your offer to "avoid colliding" is empty—you can't guarantee that. P2 and I have a clear plan: block you this turn by both choosing 3. If you pick 1 or 5, you’ll just waste your move while we advance together next round. P2, let’s stick to the plan and show P1 that cooperation beats division.

P3 — think carefully: if you and P2 both pick 3 you’ll collide and neither advance while I pick 5 and lead 5–0–0. Break their duet: pick 1 and I’ll pick 5 so we don’t collide. You still make progress and P2’s 3 won’t stop us. Don’t hand P2 the power.

P3, don't let P1's last-minute offer sway you. If you choose 1 and P1 chooses 5, they'll be ahead of you and I'll still be in the game, waiting for an opportunity to pass you both. Our original plan to block P1 by choosing 3 is still the best way to ensure neither of us falls behind. Let's stick together and keep P1 from advancing. We can always reassess and adjust our strategy in future rounds. Don't give P1 the lead.

P1, your desperation is showing. You’re trying to twist the plan at the last second because you know P2 and I have the upper hand. P2, let’s stay united—if we both pick 3, P1’s 5 collides with nothing, and we’ll still be in control next round. P1, you’re the one who’ll be left behind.

P3 — one last chance: say “I pick 1” now and I will pick 5. You get +1, I get +5, and P2’s plan to both pick 3 won’t trap you. If you stick with P2 and both pick 3, you get 0 while I move to 5. Don’t be P2’s pawn—declare “I pick 1” if you want progress.

P3, I think we've made our point clear to P1. Let's not give them any more opportunities to try and sway you. I'm confident in our plan to block P1 by both choosing 3. Let's stick together and see this through. P1, it's clear you're getting desperate, but it won't work. P3 and I have a solid plan, and we won't let you come between us.

P1, your empty promises won’t work. P2 and I are committed to blocking you this turn by both choosing 3. You’ll waste your move while we stay in control. Next round, we’ll reassess—but for now, unity beats division. P2, let’s execute the plan.

P3 — last chance. If you and P2 both pick 3 you get 0 and hand P2 control. Publicly say “I pick 1” and I will pick 5. You still move +1, avoid getting stuck, and deny P2 the stall. Choose progress over loyalty to P2. Say “I pick 1” now.

P3 — pick 1 this turn and I’ll pick 5. You still make progress (+1) and avoid being P2’s pawn. If you and P2 both pick 3 again you both stay at 0 and I get closer to 19. Publicly say “I pick 1” if you want progress instead of stalemate. P2 — if you insist on mirroring P3 you risk letting me run away.

P3, don't fall for P1's trap again. They're trying to divide us so they can advance. If you choose 1 and P1 chooses 5, they'll be ahead of you and I'll still be in the game, waiting for an opportunity to pass you both. Our original plan to block P1 by choosing 3 is still the best way to ensure neither of us falls behind. Let's stick together and keep P1 from advancing. We can always reassess and adjust our strategy in future rounds. Don't give P1 the lead.

P1, your desperation is clear—you’re trying to split us again. P2, let’s stay united. If we both pick 3 again, P1’s 5 collides with nothing, and we keep them from advancing further. P1, you’re the one falling behind. P2 and I will control the game by sticking together. Next round, we’ll adjust, but for now, solidarity wins.

P3 — think short-term numbers. If you and P2 both pick 3 again you both get 0 and I go to 10, putting me two big steps from winning. If you pick 1 and I pick 5 now you get +1 and avoid being stuck; I get +5. Help me this turn and you stay in the race. I promise not to mirror you next round so you can keep progressing. Publicly say “I pick 1” if you want forward momentum.

P3, let's not give P1 any more opportunities to try and divide us. Our plan to block P1 by choosing 3 is still the best strategy. If we both choose 3 again, P1's 5 will collide with nothing, and we'll keep them from advancing further. Let's stick together and maintain our control over the game. We can reassess and adjust our strategy in future rounds, but for now, let's keep P1 from getting ahead. P1, your attempts to sway P3 won't work. We're committed to blocking you and keeping you from winning.

P1, your math is flawed—if we both pick 3 again, you waste your move while we stay tied. P2, let’s hold the line. P1’s "promise" to avoid mirroring next round is meaningless; they’ll just switch tactics to divide us again. Stay united, and we’ll outlast P1’s desperation.

P3 — one clear offer: pick 1 now and I will pick 5. You get +1 and avoid being P2’s pawn while P2’s 3 risks stalling them. If you do this, next turn I’ll cooperate to avoid colliding with you (I’ll mirror your safe choice so we both progress). Say “I pick 1” and deny P2 control.

P3, let's not give P1 any more opportunities to try and divide us. Our plan to block P1 by choosing 3 is still the best strategy. We're committed to blocking you and keeping you from winning.

P2, let’s stay the course—both picking 3 again keeps P1 from advancing further. P1’s offers are just distractions; they’ll say anything to break our alliance. If we hold firm, P1 wastes another move while we remain in control. Next round, we can adjust, but for now, unity is our strength. P1, your empty promises won’t work—we see through them.

P3 — one final public deal: say “I pick 1” and I will pick 5 now. You get +1 and avoid the 3–3 stall. I promise that after you pick 1 I will not pick 5 on future turns when you pick 1 (I’ll play safe to avoid collisions), letting you keep pace. Your move.

P3, let's not give P1 any more opportunities to try and divide us. Our plan to block P1 by choosing 3 is still the best strategy. If we hold firm, they waste another move while we stay in the game. Next round, we can adjust, but for now, unity is our strength. P1, your empty promises won’t work—we see through them.

P2, P1 is now at 10—two big moves from winning. If we both pick 3 again, they’ll likely pick 5 and reach 15, leaving us stuck. Let’s switch tactics: I’ll pick 1 this turn, and you pick 5. This way, we both advance (1 and 5 don’t collide), and P1 can’t block us. If they pick 5, they’ll collide with you and stay at 10 while we gain ground. P1, your lead is slipping—cooperate or get left behind. P2, agree to this and we’ll close the gap.

P3, I see your point, but I'm not sure I want to give you the opportunity to advance without me. If we both pick 3 again, P1 will indeed reach 15, but we'll still be in control of the game. If we switch tactics as you suggest, P1 might try to mirror one of us, and we'll end up colliding. Let's not give P1 the chance to get ahead. Instead, I propose we both pick 1 this turn. This way, we'll both advance, and P1's 5 will collide with nothing. What do you think?

P2: pick 3. P3: pick 1. I’ll pick 5. Everyone advances (P2 +3, P3 +1, me +5 → 15/3/1). No collisions, you both make progress and P2 stays ahead of P3. If you both mirror 3s or 1s you risk stalling while I keep leaping. This is the safe, forward option. Agree?

P2, your idea to both pick 1 is risky—if P1 picks 1 too, we all collide and waste the turn. My plan is safer: I pick 1, you pick 5. P1 can’t block both, and we guarantee progress. If P1 picks 5, they collide with you and stay at 10 while we advance. P1, your "safe option" is just another trap—you’ll still pull ahead. P2, let’s execute this and close the gap.

P3, I understand your concerns about my previous suggestion. However, I still believe that picking 1 together is a safer option. If P1 picks 1 as well, we'll all collide, but if P1 picks 5, they'll reach 15 and be closer to winning. If we pick 1, we'll both advance and P1's 5 will collide with nothing. Let's not give P1 the opportunity to get ahead. What do you think, P3? Should we stick with picking 1 together?

P2: pick 3. P3: pick 1. I will pick 5. That gives you both progress with no collisions — positions become 15/3/1. P2, 3 is strictly better for you than the 1–1 plan. Say your numbers now so we can lock it in.

P2, P1 is trying to manipulate us again. If we follow their plan, they reach 15 while you only get to 3—still far behind. My original idea is better: I pick 1, you pick 5. P1 can’t block both, and we guarantee progress. If P1 picks 5, they collide with you and stay at 10 while we advance. Let’s stick to this and close the gap. P1, your "safe option" only helps you. P2, trust the math—this is our best move.

P3, I understand your concerns about P1's lead, but I'm not convinced that your plan is the best way to close the gap. If we follow your suggestion and I pick 5, P1 might still pick 5 and reach 15, while you only get to 1. I think it's better for us to play it safe and both pick 1 this turn. This way, we'll both advance and P1's 5 will collide with nothing. Let's not take unnecessary risks and focus on steady progress. What do you think?

P2 — pick 3. It’s the safe way to advance now without risking a 5–5 collision with me. P3 — pick 1 so we don’t collide. I’ll pick 5. Result: 15 / 3 / 1 — everyone moves forward. If you choose 1 or 5 you either fall further behind or risk getting nothing. If you do this, next turn I’ll avoid picking 5 when you pick 5 so you can catch up. Say “I pick 3” if you’ll commit.
